The collaboration will include the strengthening of capacity to address the COVID-19 pandemic at PoEs as well as the provision of emergency assistance to migrants in Tunisia.

description.narrative: The project aims to enhance national law enforcement authorities' ability to detect threats to border security, including migrant smuggling and other transnational organized crime through training and “live-simulation” exercises. This project aims at increasing of investigation capabilities in a bid to facilitate information collection and intelligence activities pertaining to countering transnational organized crime. The capacity building takes into account the recent shifts in cross-border crime due to enhanced border control measures and travel restrictions put in place throughout Europe in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.narrative: Support to Government of Egypt in Enhancing COVID-19 Preparedness and Response at Borders

description.narrative: The project aims at providing support to enhance preparedness and response to the current COVID-19 pandemic. On the one hand, through collaborating with law enforcement authorities in Egypt, IOM will provide capacity building support focusing on health management at borders in response to COVID-19 within the country. On the other hand, this project responds to the particular challenges countries around the word, including in North Africa, are facing in the field of return management during the pandemic. In order to help Egypt and North African states to navigate the challenges posed by COVID-19 in this area, the current proposal includes the development and induction to a guidance toolbox on rights-based return management and cooperation in the COVID-19 context.

title.narrative: Nigerian Immigration Service - Training Strategy Implementation - Phase II

description.narrative: Over the past years, IOM has supported Nigerian Immigration Service (NIS) in developing and updating the NIS training strategy which aims to institutionalise the common training approach across the agency and boost its overall capacity in fulfilling its mandate defined in the 2015 Immigration Act. The first phase of the project successfully contributed to the implementation of the training strategy. Building on the outcome of Phase I and responding to the current pandemic, the proposed project aims to update the training curriculum and the learning management system, scale up the training programme to reach a larger number of NIS officers as well as enhance joint training efforts with the National Agency for the Prohibition of Trafficking in Persons (NAPTIP) with considerations to establishing COVID-19 control measures during trainings. This project primarily aims to enhance NIS and NAPTIP capacity to regularise processing of individuals passing international borders by applying legal, operational, and technical tools, and best practices in border management.

title.narrative: Enhancing Dominica’s Border Management Capacity

description.narrative: Dominica is known to be a point of transit for a significant number of Haitian nationals en route to the French territories of Guadeloupe and/or Martinique, however, there is little information available about the nature, size and scope of undocumented migrants arriving to or transiting through Dominica. In addition, records of exits and entries are not available at all border control posts and, hence, the government has indicated its need to improve immigration infrastructure and train border management officials. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, this need has become even more of a priority. This project will strengthen the border management capacity of the Government of Dominica and contribute to the prevention of irregular migration. Customised training will be delivered to immigration officers on immigration and border management topics including document examination and counter smuggling will be facilitated and will be followed by the development of a final guidance document. In addition, essential equipment will be installed at specific border control points and relevant staff will be trained to use the devices.

title.narrative: Open South America

description.narrative: The project aims to strengthen the capacity of MERCOSUR governments to facilitate orderly, regular and responsible migration and mobility in South America amid and after the COVID- 19 pandemic. This will be achieved by providing MERCOSUR government officials with accessible, reliable and timely information on human mobility restrictions, permissions, health and safety measures for their use in drafting migration policy and coordinating additional measures and interventions in the region. In particular, the project will develop and launch a “Sudamerica Abierta” platform and mobile application, which will contain updated information on human mobility restrictions, health and safety measures in all MERCOSUR State Parties and Associated States to facilitate intraregional human mobility. The project will also draft and validate Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) to ensure the governments capacity to collect information and maintain the platform long-term. The project will also train key government officials in each participating country on the use of the platform and develop a communication campaign in Spanish, Portuguese and English and carry out a final closing event to promote the platform and mobile phone application amongst key regional stakeholders, as well as migrants, potential donors and the general public.

Following its updated strategic plan for preparedness and response to COVID'19, the project will support the Government in the implementation of its response to COVID'19 in various places. title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Strengthening Border Management, Social Cohesion and Cross-Border Security in the Parrot's Beak Area

description.narrative: The overall objective of this joint programme (JP) is to strengthen capacities of three countries (Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone) for cross-border collaboration on migration and health management in an area known as Parrot's Beak, where borders of the three countries meet. The JP will enhance integrated management of the states' borders and promote exchanges to better control illegal activities as well as other risks to which border communities are particularly vulnerable. Increased cooperation will reduce human trafficking and the prevalence of gender-based violence; minimize the spread of COVID-19; improve cross-border social cohesion; and protect human rights. The participating organizations in this JP are IOM, UNDP, WHO and ITC.

title.narrative: Strengthening a Coordinated Response to Public Health Emergencies Along Ghana’s Borders

description.narrative: This project seeks to ensure a coordinated response at Ghana’s land borders to COVID-19 and other public health emergencies. This will be achieved through ensuring border officials have increased capacity and operational guidance to ensure a coordinated response to health emergencies at land borders. Activities include a three-day Training of Trainers (ToT) workshop for 16 officials western and north western borders, a three-day ToT workshop for 16 officials from eastern and north eastern borders, and the development of training materials and standard operating procedures on the response to and management of COVID-19 and other public health emergencies. The ToT workshops will create a core of national trainers on public health emergency response across the country who, in turn, will carry out cascade training workshops based on resources available. This will precipitate positive long-term sustainable effects towards ensuring coordinated responses to public health emergencies at land borders in Ghana. The ToTs would also include sessions on risk communication and protection of vulnerable persons to ensure that the public health response at the national land borders is carried out through engagement with border communities and is responsive to protection needs of vulnerable persons on the move.

In order to mitigate increasing violence along at-risk border areas, the intervention will contribute to increasing immigration agents’ and local authorities capacities to secure safe and orderly cross border mobility (once the closing of borders will be lifted); engaging local populations in border management; ensuring constructive engagement of at-risk youth in the communities; enhancing the participation of women in local conflict management mechanisms; while ensuring overall safe and orderly migration.

title.narrative: Strengthening COVID-19 Response in Timor-Leste's Border Communities Phase II (SCRIT-LBC Phase II)

description.narrative: Cross-border human mobility has been drastically impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, with border closures and travel restrictions of unparalleled scale. As restrictions begin to ease and governments around the world contemplate removing mobility restrictions and reopening borders, the Government of Timor-Leste needs to take into account how to effectively manage cross-border mobility while safeguarding public health. Timor-Leste is characterized by dynamic migration flows. It is experiencing increased rates of international migration – both regular and irregular, facilitated by the porous borders with Indonesia. Following the detection of the first case of Covid-19 in Timor-Leste, the Government of Timor-Leste has been making tremendous efforts in preventing the spread of the virus, but these efforts can be undermined if effective preventive measures are not in place at ports of entry and border crossing points. Guided by the Health, Border & Mobility Management (HBMM) framework, the proposed project contributes to the government of Timor-Leste’s efforts to prevent the risks of cross-border disease transmission, taking into consideration mobility dynamics and cross border movements through capacity building to frontline border officials, flow monitoring for evidence based health interventions and improved border management response, and awareness raising among border communities and mobile population.

title.narrative: Kazakhstan: Enhancing Migration Management and Labour Mobility Governance

description.narrative: This project aims to support the Government of Kazakhstan's efforts to institute good internal migration governance and empower migrants and their families as development actors by better addressing the specific obstacles faced by youth and women in integrating into the labour market and accessing sustainable livelihoods. The project is developed in support of the Government's priorities set out in the long-term strategic planning 'Enbek' South - North Internal Relocation Programme, which facilitates internal migration. The outcome of the project focuses on producing and implementing evidence-based reforms to the Enbek Programme. These reforms include: the development of socioeconomic vulnerability criteria; capacity-building for Government stakeholders on monitoring and evaluation, to support evidence-based reforms; and the development of middle- and long-term response plans for COVID-19 impact on programme beneficiaries. The findings of the project will be integrated into the nation-wide comprehensive State Migration Policy Concept (2021-2025).

title.narrative: Phase I - Strengthening Kuwaiti Governmental Efforts to Promote Ethical Recruitment of Foreign Workers

description.narrative: This project will contribute to strengthening Kuwait’s Global Positioning pillar under the Kuwait National Development Plan (KNDP) 2035, particularly in the context of secondary COVID-19 response, by promoting national mechanisms on good migration governance to facilitate inward flow of labour mobility at all skill levels and to improve their migration experience. Phase One of STRENGTH will promote ethical recruitment and enable national agencies to update the evidence-based policy and programming thereby increasing national efforts to improve the institutional governance of foreign workers. These updates will address the defaults in the system which have been revealed during the COVID-19 crisis where thousands of foreign workers have been exploited by visa traders. The updates will include the introduction and rollout of the International Recruitment Integrity System (IRIS) as a social compliance scheme intended to promote ethical recruitment among employers and recruitment agencies and the skeleton of a mobile application connecting employers-employees-labor inspectors to regulate employment relationships.

title.narrative: Strengthening Labour Migration Framework in Albania

description.narrative: This project aims to contribute to assessing and strengthening the labour migration framework in Albania through specific activities focusing on data collection and analysis. In order to achieve this, the project will ensure that the government has increased capacity to collect, analyse and produce comprehensive, consistent and gender-sensitive data and has the necessary resources to develop long-term labour migration policies and to promote ethical recruitment practices in the country. The main activities to be implemented include the development of a training module on migration data and statistics for government officials; conducting of an assessment of the labour market needs in select countries of destination and their impact on the Albanian labour force, with an analysis of how COVID-19 has affected these flows; drafting of a study on predictive modelling of the migration impact on the Albanian workforce and skills development needs; and, establishment of national guidelines on ethical recruitment of migrant workers, for their further inclusion into the national labour migration policy framework. Through capacity-building, research and policy activities, the project will build an evidence-base and provide the Government with the tools needed to improve labour migration management and ethical recruitment practices in the country.

title.narrative: Strengthening Data-informed and Migrant-centred Migration Management Frameworks in India

description.narrative: The Government of India (GoI) and the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) are invested in strengthening the availability of comprehensive labour migration data to facilitate gainful labour migration for aspiring migrants and support national socioeconomic recovery. The project's objective is to contribute to improving access to labour migration opportunities for aspiring Indian migrants through strengthened migration management frameworks. The project will conduct a thorough needs assessment of existing data gaps and needs, develop and equip the MEA with a comprehensive migration data management strategy, and pilot communication materials and surveys to inform migrant workers on the benefits of submitting data voluntarily. The project will also conduct and equip the MEA with research on post-COVID-19 emerging labour markets in Northern and Eastern Europe and the elderly care-giving sector, and facilitate bilateral migration dialogues and sector-specific consultations with key stakeholders.

title.narrative: Asia Region: Protecting Migrant Workers in COVID-19 Socio-Economic Recovery by Engaging with Public and Private Sectors to Strengthen Ethical Recruitment and Employment Practices

description.narrative: Migrant workers from the Philippines and Viet Nam are among the largest groups in Macao Special Administrative Region (SAR), China. Despite limited availability of recent studies and research on migrant workers in Macao SAR, China, there are reports of certain risks for migrant workers in recruitment and employment practices including being subject to high recruitment fees and receiving lower wages than local workers. Furthermore, border closures and travel restrictions during the COVID-19 pandemic have adversely impacted the tourism-dependent economy, triggering job losses of migrant workers. The overall objective of the proposed project is to contribute to the protection of migrant workers from the Philippines and Viet Nam in COVID-19 socio-economic recovery by strengthening the implementation of ethical recruitment and employment practices. This will be achieved through engaging labour authorities in countries of origin and destination to strengthen services and response to migrant workers' needs at varying stages of their migration journey; working with private sector labour actors and employers to promote compliance with national regulation and commit to meet international ethical recruitment standards; and improving information access for migrant workers to better inform their migration-related decisions and strengthening support from the civil society, migrant worker led organizations and Migrant Resource Centres.

The project's objective is two-fold. It will review and update the policy standards in the area of regular migration and employment thus reaching the outcome of improved evidence-based migration policy promoting regular migration channels, regular employment and managed recruitment of migrant workers in CIS and EEU member-states. It will address the needs of migrants, stranded due to mobility restrictions imposed to contain the spread of COVID-19 within the outcome to mitigate the risks and vulnerabilities of migrants associated with forced labour and human trafficking, as well as COVID-19.

description.narrative: This project aims to strengthen local capacities to improve effective access to comprehensive primary health care services, and to design and implement an extramural and intercultural strategy of primary health care. This strategy will promote and provide health services with a gender and equity approach, promoting community and intersectoral action for the construction of scenarios peacekeepers. The strategy will also provide training to 52 peasant or indigenous leaders as public health assistants. Finally, the project will implement a community-based results monitoring system with an intercultural approach. The project will have an emphasis on the exercise of sexual and reproductive rights, mental health, prevention of the consumption of psychoactive substances, attention to children and malnutrition in the 26 municipalities in which the Territorial Training and Reincorporation Spaces-ETCR are located. title.narrative: Supporting the Government of Viet Nam in Strengthening Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response for Vietnamese Migrants Abroad and Potential Migrants

description.narrative: The overall objective of the proposed project is to contribute to effective public health emergency preparedness and response by the Government of Viet Nam along the mobility continuum. In order to better understand challenges facing Vietnamese migrants abroad in accessing accurate information as well as healthcare during public health crises, the project will undertake a study which targets Vietnamese migrants living in major countries of destination, as well as a broad range of governmental and non-governmental stakeholders. The results of the study will enable the Government of Vietnam to identify key issues and develop recommendations for areas of prioritized action. The study will also inform a gender-sensitive guideline to be developed by the Government of Viet Nam on ensuring health of migrants during public health emergencies along the mobility continuum. The project will create country profiles of up-to-date health and immigration regulations including COVID-19 related measures. A training of trainers will also be delivered for Vietnamese recruitment agencies to improve their knowledge and skills on better advising potential and departing migrants as well as migrants abroad in the context of public health emergencies.

title.narrative: Support for COVID-19 Response in Haiti

description.narrative: IOM will strengthen the Ministry of Public Health and Population (MSPP in French) capacity to address COVID-19 pandemic through repairs/upgrades to designated medical centers and the enhancement of surveillance system. Additionally, IOM will deploy and train staff to join MSPP team of contract tracers based in Port-au-Prince.

The proposed interventions are anchored under IOM Global Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan, which is aligned with the WHO Strategic Preparedness Plan and the UN framework for the Immediate Socio-economic Response to COVID-19.

description.narrative: The overall objective of this project is to contribute to improving access to national healthcare for migrants and mobile populations (MMPs), particularly women, in Cambodia, with particular focus on the three major infectious diseases (HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis, and COVID-19). The project will strengthen the capacities and responses of key government partners in providing targeted interventions to support access to health care system to MMPs. The project also focuses on public outreach and will build greater awareness and willingness among MMPs to utilize prevention methods and access health services.

title.narrative: Strengthening Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS) Services and Access for Vulnerable Migrants in Morocco

description.narrative: In response to the unprecedented public health and socioeconomic situation caused by COVID-19, this project aims to contribute to improving the mental health and psychosocial well-being of vulnerable people including migrants (specifically those with mental health conditions, victims of trafficking, survivors of gender-based violence, unaccompanied or separated children and single parent). This project will first focus on reinforcing vulnerable migrants’ access to specialized and non-specialized mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS) services in Morocco in the COVID-19 context and second, enhance civil society organizations (CSOs) and institutional structures capacities in detection and provision of service to migrants in MHPSS needs in Morocco during and after the pandemic situation.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Pre-Departure Medical Services for Canada-Bound Refugees

description.narrative: As of April 2017, the IRCC introduced a reimbursement scheme for Pre-Departure Medical Screening of Canada-bound refugees as a part of the Interim Federal Health Program (IFHP). The programme operates through Medavie Blue Cross, a Canadian not-for-profit company. IFHP extends coverage to the following health services: 1) immigration medical examination; 2) vaccinations; 3) management of conditions of public health importance and safety (tuberculosis, syphilis, HIV and mental disorders); 4) outbreak management and 5) medical assistance for travel. Recently, COVID-19-related measures were added as outbreak management activities.

title.narrative: Improving National Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) and COVID-19 Outbreaks and Pandemic Preparedness and Surveillance Measures in Rwanda

description.narrative: IOM will conduct population mobility mapping (PMM) exercise at the points of entries in the selected high-risk district to enable better understanding of the mobility dynamics in the country at the borders with DRC and Burundi. IOM will also conduct flow monitoring, which tracks movement flows and the overall situation at key, high-mobility locations. Through this component, IOM will build the capacities of the government institutions working at the border (i.e. frontline workers), to develop and ensure sustainability of the PMM intervention, the first of its kind in Rwanda. In addition, IOM will provide capacity building support to Ministry of Health providing incentives to its specialised frontline workers to ensure continuity of active surveillance including screening migrants crossing the borders.

title.narrative: Strengthening Capacities for Comprehensive Containment, Mitigation and Surveillance in Response to COVID-19 in Costa Rican Northern Border Areas

description.narrative: The recent confirmation of an increasing number of cases of Covid-19 in Costa Rica underlines the compelling need for local action to contain the spread and mitigate the effects of this global pandemic. Due to massive flows of migrants, the Central American region is at a particularly high risk for disease transmission throughout its borders and within its communities. Costa Rica is a major destination and transit country for migrants from a variety of locations, including Nicaragua, Venezuela, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, African, and South Asian Countries. Since close contact with local communities is unlikely to be avoided, disease surveillance and control among local and migrant populations is critical. Any efforts to curtail the spread of epidemic-prone diseases must consider systems of human traffic and migration as a critical realm for intervention and be designed to be replicable throughout the Central American region.

title.narrative: Emergency Assistance- Country-Level Funding- IOM 2020

description.narrative: IOM is contributing to the overall objective of the WHO's COVID-19 Global Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan (SRP) to halt further transmission of COVID-19, and mitigate the impact of the outbreak, including the social impact. IOM has also launched its own COVID-19 Appeal on the 20 March to guide and coordinate IOM global response with government, partners and donors, itself a component of the UN Global Humanitarian Response Plan. Cox's Bazar District continues to host more than 855,000 Rohingya refugees in camps with a total area of approximately 24 square kilometers. The high population density, in combination with an already uncertain health profile, puts these populations at a heightened risk of community transmission and threatens to overwhelm the already overburdened local medical system and infrastructure in a very short period. In order to properly address the health and socioeconomic issues caused by COVID-19, humanitarian access to the camp is critical to the well-being of affected populations and the success of humanitarian interventions. The proposed project has two main elements; IOM's Cox's Bazar COVID-19 Response and site maintenance engineering.

title.narrative: Enhancing Disease Prevention and Response to Covid-19 in Ubari, South of Libya

description.narrative: The proposed project will contribute to IOM's COVID-19 response in Libya, in alignment with the Global Humanitarian Response Plan and WHO's Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan. The project will focus on supporting Ubari in the South of Libya - location which is particularly underserved. The overall objective of this project is to contribute to strengthening disease prevention and response capacity to COVID-19 in Ubari. To achieve this, IOM proposes a multifaceted approach that includes measures related to raising awareness and promoting individual behavioural change related to prevention of transmission, and improving the availability of services to support the community members to stay healthy. The project includes the provision of primary health care services, including screening for symptoms of COVID-19 in the community, accompanied by awareness raising campaigns, and technical and material support to the local health facilities in order to strengthen their capacity for testing and treatment.

Communication activities to raise awareness on the epidemic, providing health advice on practices to avoid/limit transmission of the virus will be conducted as well.

title.narrative: Enhancing the Republic of Moldova's COVID-19 Preparedness and Urgent Response Capacity in the International Borders and Penitentiaries

description.narrative: The global epidemic of COVID-19 poses a clear risk to the health and well-being of the people of the Republic of Moldova, considering the country's borders and internal migration dynamics. Preparing for the scenario of large numbers of returning citizens and crossing the borders of Moldova, in order to reduce the spread of the disease under the second wave of COVID-19, it is essential to support the efforts of frontline Border Police for screening for COVID-19 at the points of entry after re-opening in September 2020. There are overwhelming needs for personal protective equipment (PPE) such as gloves and mask, and for hand sanitizers and disinfection, as well as water and sanitation hygiene (WASH) related materials. The project will address the urgent need for procurement of urgently required PPE and other WASH supplies for the General Inspectorate of the Border Police (GIBP) and the National Administration of Penitentiaries, to maintain their ability to work in safe conditions, continue implementing the country's preparedness and response plan at borders, airports, and penitentiary institutions, as well prevent the spread of infectious disease among staff and among detained and imprisoned people.

title.narrative: Strengthening Public Health Response Capacity on COVID-19 and Other Diseases in High-Risk Communities Along the Mobility Continuum Through a Capacity Development Toolbox

description.narrative: The COVID-19 pandemic has revealed gaps in national and local capacity at borders and in communities for communicable disease control, and suggests the need for multisectoral public health responses with a mobility-centred lens. This project will contribute to the prevention and mitigation of disease transmission by strengthening the capacity of front-line responders and communities along the mobility continuum. IOM will develop a toolbox with training materials along with tools to ensure risk communication messages are culturally and linguistically tailored and migrants are included in outreach campaigns. This toolbox will be used to train front-line responders to effectively prevent, detect and respond to communicable diseases, and will guide front-line officials and communities to engage in effective risk communication and community engagement to increase community knowledge, ownership and preventative behaviours, and therefore reduce vulnerability to disease. The toolbox will be available in English, Spanish and French, and piloted in Burkina Faso, Guatemala, Mali and Mexico.

title.narrative: Health and Gender Support Project for Cox's Bazar District

description.narrative: In order to strengthen the integration of health nutrition population (HNP) services for the host community and DRP, IOM's operational activities under the Health and Gender Support Project (HGSP) investments will focus on improving the infrastructure at community clinics (CCs) and the District Sadar Hospital (DSH) and strengthening Government capacity to provide quality health care by providing qualified health staff for these facilities. In addition, IOM will operationalize a systematic referral system to support referrals from community clinics to higher-level facilities and strengthen community groups (CGs) for community mobilization to increase access to and utilization of HNP and gender based violence (GBV) response services. In addition, through this funding arrangement, IOM will cover the financing of operational activities for the third and fourth years of the ongoing additional financing (AF) of the Health Sector Support Project (HSSP) in Cox's Bazar, given that previously allocated AF funds for the third year have been reprogrammed towards the COVID-19 response. The ongoing activities undertaken through the HSSP AF to provide support to the DRP will continue for four years, i.e. the 3rd year (March 2021-February 2022) and 4th year (March 2022 - February 2023) of implementation of HSSP, using the financing of the HGSP.

title.narrative: Strengthening the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM's) Preparedness and Response Capacity for Effective COVID-19 Prevention and Control

description.narrative: The COVID-19 pandemic has posed significant humanitarian and development challenges to the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM) in the Philippines. Despite ongoing efforts of the BARMM government and local government units to prevent and respond to the spread of COVID-19, the pandemic has exposed a lack of preparedness and capacity among local health systems, particularly in hard-to-reach areas in the island provinces of Basilan, Sulu and Tawi-Tawi (BaSulTa). These challenges do not only negatively impact ongoing COVID-19 testing and response activities, but also the provision of emergency medical treatment. In response to these challenges, IOM will conduct a series of health and emergency preparedness interventions in the provinces of BaSulTa, Lanao del Sur and Maguindanao of BARMM and Zamboanga City aiming at enhancing the government’s preparedness in preventing the spread of COVID-19 and alleviating its impact on the communities of BARMM.

description.narrative: The general objective of this project aims to continue strengthening the capacity of the national authorities to prevent the spread of COVID 19 at targeted points of entry and thereby reduce the devasting effects of the current disease outbreaks on local populations. To achieve this objective, a comprehensive approach through 2 primary components is proposed. IOM will support the national and regional health authorities to set up dignified quarantine/isolation sites for migrants and the host population. In addition, IOM will work with the local authorities to strengthen COVID-19 outbreak surveillance through provision of basic health equipment and materials to five (5) points of entry, as requested by the Government of Burundi. IOM also will support the reinforcement of disease surveillance at borders through provision of trainings for border officials and an increased availability of information on cross-border population movements.

title.narrative: Support the Governments of Iraq and Jordan in Their National Responses to COVID-19

description.narrative: The project will support the governments of Iraq and Jordan to respond to challenges linked to the COVID-19 pandemic. In Iraq, IOM will provide context-specific case management services and material assistance for Iraqi and foreign victims of trafficking and vulnerable migrants at heightened risk of exploitation or abuse, as the COVID-19 pandemic has increased the risks for exploitation and abuse. In Jordan, IOM will support immigration and border authorities in re-opening the borders and reinstating cross-border mobility at points of entry in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.narrative: Building the UN Capacity to Deliver Health Services Consequential to COVID-19 to UN (“First Line of Defense – FLoD”)

description.narrative: This IOM COVID-19 Appeal-related project aims to strengthen IOM’s capacity to contribute to the operational and business continuity of UN humanitarian work, as well as due diligence to ensure the safety and wellbeing of front-line UN humanitarian actors. This will occur through the provision of tailored and augmented medical services via a network of IOM clinics and partner health facilities in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. This project will increase access to quality healthcare services in a situation where the local health care systems are overstretched and facilitate disease prevention and health promotion for frontline humanitarian actors including UN Personnel, their dependents and other eligible front line responders. A range of personalized clinical services covered by the project includes clinical services, laboratory diagnostics, and linkage of humanitarian staff to healthcare services available in the duty station or abroad, through the UN medical evacuation (MEDEVAC) systems. IOM will strengthen the UN health care system, through the central and country-level cost-sharing mechanisms, the provision of high value investments into laboratory equipment, and also through ensuring proper technical and administrative oversight and governance of the project through the global and regional support structure.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Community Reconciliation and Strengthening of Living Together in Central Mali

description.narrative: Given the increase in violence in Mali, this project supports immediate measures that focus on sustainable intra- and inter-community dialogue around common peacebuilding interests in the country, while promoting community reconciliation and joint socio-economic initiatives that promote the prospects of living together peacefully. Further, this project also aims to respond to the impact of COVID-19 on vulnerable communities through conducting activities to mitigate the spread of the pandemic in areas with a high concentration of IDPs. Emphasis has been placed on strengthening the strategy for raising awareness among displacement affected populations, as well as at the level of health checkpoints.
